title-group.article-title: Net shape preparation and bending properties of tapered three-dimensional braided composites

author-notes.corresp: Jianyong Yu, Modern Textile Institute, 1882 Yan’an Rd. (west), Shanghai 200051, China. Email: yu_jianyong@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The yarn-reduction technique and the yarn-addition technique were introduced to net shape prepare tapered three-dimensional braided composites. Considering that the processes of yarn reduction and yarn addition were mutually inverse, this paper mainly shed light on the former. Two types of yarn-reduction process, the column yarn-reduction process and row unit yarn-reduction process, were discussed in the architectures of preforms thus formed and bending behaviors of corresponding composites. Results show that the principle of these two techniques is that the braiding rules should not be disturbed after yarn reduction or yarn addition. Orientation degrees and lengths of some rearranged yarns are increased in the second step after yarn reduction, whereas the other rearranged yarns only reverse their orientation directions, then the yarn trajectories are the same as before yarn reduction in subsequent steps. Bending properties of the row unit yarn-reduction composites are slightly higher than those of the column yarn-reduction composites and significantly better than the cut composites. The primary failure mechanism of the yarn-reduction composites is yarn breakage, while the dominant failure mechanisms of the cut composites are matrix cracking and interfacial debonding.

body.p: Three-dimensional (3D) braided composites have excellent out-of-plane mechanical properties, low delamination tendency, high energy absorbing capability and outstanding fatigue resistance,1,2 which makes them strong candidates in the fields of aerospace industry, automobile industry and biomedical engineering.3–6 Furthermore, the most attractive advantage of 3D braiding is its capability to net shape produce composites with special geometric shapes. For example, Kostar and Chou7 fabricated composites with complex rectangular cross-sections by the Universal Method, the basic concept of which was to subdivide the complex cross-sections into finite rectangular elements and then braid the elements in groups. Zhang et al.8 studied the microstructures of the braided preforms with complex rectangular cross-sections and established the interior, surface and corner unit cells in the joint region. Sun et al.9 explored the design and manufacture technology of 3D integrated braided composite support with irregular shape. The braiding technology of the irregular preform, the determination of process parameters of resin transfer molding and the design of consolidation molds for the composite support were researched.

However, the cross-sectional sizes of most 3D braided composites are not constant in practical applications. Instead, their sectional sizes usually change along the length direction to form a tapered shape, such as wind turbine blades and aircraft propellers.10,11 The traditional method to manufacture tapered 3D braided composites is by cutting their uniform counterparts. Obviously, the structural integrity and mechanical properties of the composite products are seriously damaged by cutting. Meanwhile, the production efficiency is low and the manufacturing cost becomes high, too.12 Therefore, attention has been paid to the net shape preparation of tapered 3D braided composites. Li13 proposed a method to prepare preforms involving discrete cross-section decrease. A given number of yarns did not interlace but simply remained straight on the surface or in the interior of the preform, then these yarns were cut away at both free ends after the braiding process was finished. Braided composites involving continuous cross-section decrease were constructed by Kostar and Chou7 using a four-step row and column braider. The preform was divided into a reasonable number of discrete segments firstly, and then a single layer of unbraided yarns was removed at the end of each segment to reduce the cross-section. The generated series of discontinuities could be smoothed out during consolidation and the composites had a continuously changing shape. Liu et al.14 produced tapered 3D braided composites by the unit yarn-reduction technique using polyester yarns and epoxy resin. Preform microstructures were depicted by the control volume method and differences in the interlacing patterns before and after yarn reduction were analyzed. Flexural behaviors of the unit yarn-reduction composites, cut composites and uniform composites were studied, too.

Based on four-step row and column braiding process, the yarn-reduction and the yarn-addition techniques were introduced to prepare tapered 3D braided composites net-shapedly. Considering that the processes of yarn reduction and yarn addition were mutually inverse, this paper mainly shed light on the former. Column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites with the same shape were produced. Models of the yarn trajectories formed after yarn reduction were established and equations of yarn length and orientation angle were derived. Bending properties in the tapered regions of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites were compared and their failure mechanisms were discussed, too.

sec.title: Materials and specimen preparation
sec.p:
T700 12 K carbon fibers (Toray Company) were used to fabricate the preforms with a four-step row and column braider. The initial braiding array of the yarn-reduction preforms was [12 × 20]. When the preforms reached a desired length, the column yarn-reduction technique or the row unit yarn-reduction technique was implemented, respectively, and the braiding array became [12 × 16]. The following braiding cycles were continued until the yarn-reduction preforms were finished. Meanwhile, uniform preforms with a [12 × 20] braiding array were also fabricated. Then the mixture of Araldite® LY1564 epoxy resin and Aradur 3486 curing agent (Huntsman (Shanghai) Co., Ltd) with a weight ratio of 100:34 was injected into all the preforms by vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding (VARTM). The composites were pre-cured at 60°C for 3 hours and post-cured at 35°C for 24 hours under the vacuum pressure of 0.075 MPa. Finally, the uniform composites were cut to the same shape as the yarn-reduction composites. Fiber volume fractions of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites were about 45%. Schematic diagrams of the tapered composites are shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Schematic diagrams of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites: (a) length × width; (b) length × thickness.

sec.title: Measurements and characterizations
sec.p: Photographs of the column yarn-reduction preform and the row unit yarn-reduction preform were taken by a Canon IXUS105 digital camera (Canon (China) Co., Ltd) to observe their architectures.

Three-point bending tests were performed on a MTS 810 universal testing machine (MTS Co., USA). The testing span was 176 mm and the crosshead speed was 2 mm min−1. Tapered regions of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites were placed right below the crosshead. A photograph of the equipment and the attached sample during the examination process is shown in Figure 2. Both the crosshead displacement and the load were recorded until apparent damage appeared in the composites. Five specimens of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites were tested, respectively, and their average bending strengths and bending moduli were calculated according to the standard ISO 178.15 The width of the tapered cross-section could be estimated by Equation (1): (1)b=12(b1+b2) where b is the width of the tapered cross-section, in mm, and b1 and b2 are the widths before and after cross-section decrease, respectively, in mm. Figure 2.
The equipment and the attached sample during three-point bending test.

After bending tests, fracture surfaces of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites were examined by a DXS-10ACRT scanning electron microscope (SEM; Shanghai Electron Optical Technology Institutes) to analyze their failure mechanisms.

sec.title: Mechanisms of the yarn-reduction technique and the yarn-addition technique
sec.p:
The four-step row and column braiding process involves four distinct Cartesian movements of yarn groups, termed rows and columns. As can be seen in Figure 3, alternate rows firstly move a prescribed distance relative to each other in step 1; then columns move in alternating directions in step 2. The movements in steps 3 and 4 are simply opposite to those in steps 1 and 2, respectively. A complete set of four steps is called a machine cycle and the preform length increases as the machine cycle repeats. Because of the periodicity of four-step row and column braiding, uniform composites can be constructed by the duplication of their unit cells. From the perspective of structural repeating units, tapered composites can be net shape prepared either by the reduction of their repeating units, namely the surface yarn-reduction unit and the interior yarn-reduction unit, or by the addition of the surface yarn-addition unit and the interior yarn-addition unit. There are three yarns with two of them in one same row or same column for a surface unit and four yarns in two adjacent rows and columns for an interior unit. To ensure that the four-step movements are not disturbed after yarn reduction or yarn addition, the reduction units or the addition units should exist in all rows of the braiding array to change the sectional width and exist in all columns to change the sectional thickness. In this way the arrangement of the side yarn array is still regular and subsequent braiding cycles can go on. Figure 3.
The four-step row and column braiding process: (a) original; (b) step 1; (c) step 2; (d) step 3; (4) step 4.

According to the distribution of the reduction units, there exists the column yarn-reduction process, the row yarn-reduction process and the row unit or the column unit yarn-reduction process. Reduction units are located in two adjacent columns throughout the thickness direction in the column yarn-reduction process to decrease the sectional width, and they are located in two adjacent rows in the row yarn-reduction process to decrease the sectional thickness. When the sectional width is reduced by the row unit yarn-reduction process, reduction units in neighboring rows should be arranged in different columns. When the column unit yarn-reduction process is used to reduce the sectional thickness, reduction units in neighboring columns should be arranged in different rows. Similarly, the yarn-addition technique can be divided into the column yarn-addition process, row yarn-addition process and the row unit or the column unit yarn-addition process, too.

Procedures to implement the yarn-reduction technique are as follows.14 Yarns in the reduction units are cut down at the free ends firstly, so the positions of the reduction units become vacant. Next, a smaller braiding array is built by yarn rearrangement. If the sectional width needs to be decreased, yarns in the same rows and outside columns of the reduction units are moved horizontally in turn to fill the vacancies until yarns in the outermost columns are also moved. If the sectional thickness needs to be decreased, yarns in the same columns and outside rows of the reduction units are moved vertically in turn to fill the vacancies until yarns in the outermost rows are also moved. After the above yarn rearrangement, subsequent machine cycles could continue in a smaller array and net shape preparation of tapered preforms is realized. Procedures to implement the yarn-addition technique can be stated as follows. When the sectional width needs to be increased, yarns in the same rows and outside columns of the addition units are moved outside horizontally in turn, then the addition units are moved outside, too. Likewise, yarns in the same columns and outside rows of the addition units together with the addition units are all moved outside vertically in order to increase the sectional thickness. After the above yarn rearrangement, the positions of the addition units are vacant. Secondly, new yarns are added to fill the vacancies, so that subsequent machine cycles could continue in a larger braiding array. Finally, unintertwined parts of the added yarns are cut away from the braids; thus, net shape preparation of tapered preforms is realized.

The column and row processes are easy to design and they can be employed even if the braiding array is rather small. Design of the row unit and column unit processes is more complicated, but structural defects caused by these two processes are tiny and dispersive. Figure 4 shows a drum-shaped sleeve braided integrally by three times of unit yarn reduction and three times of unit yarn addition. It can be found that yarn reduction and yarn addition are mutually inverse, so the yarn-reduction technique is taken as a representative and studied in detail. The column yarn-reduction process and the row unit yarn-reduction process used in this paper are illustrated in Figure 5, where • and ○ represent the reduced yarns and unreduced yarns, respectively. Digits listed vertically and horizontally are the row numbers and column numbers, respectively. Arrows indicate the movement directions when unreduced yarns fill vacancies. Figure 4.
Photograph of a drum-shaped sleeve braided by three times unit yarn reduction and three times unit yarn addition. Figure 5.
The column yarn-reduction process (a) and the row unit yarn-reduction process (b) used in this paper.

sec.title: Architectures of the yarn-reduction preforms
sec.p:
Figure 6(a) and (b) show the photographs of the column yarn-reduction preform and the row unit yarn-reduction preform in their tapered regions. There are no obvious free yarn ends or pores on the surface of the two preforms and the sectional widths are both contracted gradually to form smoothly trapezoidal shapes. Due to the removal of the reduced yarns and the rearrangement of the unreduced yarns, special architectures appear near the yarn-reduction cross-sections. Yarn lengths within one pitch become a little longer and yarn orientations vary slightly. After several machine cycles, preform architectures are the same as before yarn reduction. Figure 6.
Photographs of the column yarn-reduction preform (a) and the row unit yarn-reduction preform (b) in their tapered regions.

Models of the yarn trajectories formed after yarn-reduction are established according to the row unit yarn-reduction process shown in Figure 5(b). When the surface reduction unit 05-14-15 is taken away, yarn 03 and yarn 13 occupy the places of yarn 05 and yarn 15, respectively, after yarn rearrangement, and reach the positions where yarn 05 and yarn 15 should be in the following steps, respectively, as shown in Figure 7(a). It can be found that the orientation degree and length of yarn 03 are both increased in the second step after yarn reduction. However, yarn 13 only reverses its orientation direction and there are no changes in the yarn length and orientation degree. In the following steps, the yarn trajectories return to conventional four-step patterns again. Due to the removal of the interior reduction unit 44-45-54-55, the orientation degree of yarn 42 is larger and its length becomes longer in the second step, while yarn 52 reverses its orientation direction only. Then their yarn trajectories are the same as before yarn reduction, as revealed in Figure 7(b). Figure 7.
Yarn trajectories formed after the removal of a surface reduction unit (a) or an interior reduction unit (b). The first digits indicate row numbers and the second digits indicate column numbers.

To further analyze preform microstructures, the following assumptions are made: projections of yarn cross-sections on the machine bed are elliptical with the major radius a and minor radius b. The braiding process is quite stable and the preform advances half a pitch length every two steps. As a result, the orientation angle and length of yarn 03 in the second step after removal of the surface reduction unit 05-14-15 can be derived by (2)tanθs=44a2+b2h (3)ls=h2+64a2+16b22
The orientation angle and length of yarn 42 in the second after removal of the interior reduction unit 44-45-54-55 can be expressed by (4)tanθi=49a2+b2h (5)li=h2+144a2+16b22

Whereas the orientation angle and yarn length formed every half machine cycle in conventional four-step braiding process can be characterized by (6)tanθ=4a2+b2h (7)l=h2+16a2+16b22 where h is the pitch length, θs and θi are the orientation angles of yarn 03 and yarn 42, respectively, in the second step after yarn-reduction, ls and li are the lengths of yarn 03 and yarn 42, respectively, in the second step after yarn-reduction and θ and l are the orientation angle and yarn length, respectively, formed every half machine cycle in conventional four-step braiding. It is obvious that θs > θ, θi > θ and ls > l, li > l.

sec.title: Bending properties of the yarn-reduction composites and the cut composites
sec.p:
Load-deflection curves of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites are shown in Figure 8. The load-deflection response reveals that all the composites behave in a linear manner up to failure. The row unit yarn-reduction composites show rapid load rise and the highest maximum load. Conversely, the cut composites show slow load rise and the lowest maximum load. Subsequent to the peak load point, load begins to decline sharply and specimen failure occurs. The composites are all damaged in the tapered regions but eventually no specimen separations are observed. The average bending strengths and bending moduli in the tapered regions of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites are plotted in Figure 9. It can be found that the row unit yarn-reduction composites have the maximum strength of 638 MPa and the highest modulus of 66 GPa. Bending strengths of the column yarn-reduction composites and the cut composites are 556 MPa and 407 MPa, and their bending moduli are 60 GPa and 44 GPa, respectively. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Tukey’s pairwise multiple comparisons are employed to compare the property differences. A p-value less than 0.05 is considered significant. Results indicate that bending properties of the row unit yarn-reduction composites and the column yarn-reduction composites are significantly higher than those of the cut composites (p < 0.05). However, the row unit composites have slightly better bending properties than the column yarn-reduction composites, with no statistically significant difference (p > 0.05). Figure 8.
Load-deflection curves of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites. Figure 9.
Bending strengths (a) and bending moduli (b) in the tapered regions of the column yarn-reduction composites, row unit yarn-reduction composites and cut composites.

The reason why cut composites have the weakest bending modulus is that cutting brings serious damage to the integrate architectures; as a result, larger deformations are yielded in the cut composites than in the yarn-reduction composites under equal load. The lowest bending strength of the cut composites is mainly caused by the following reasons. Firstly, yarns could not carry the applied bending load but buckle or slip out from the loosened fiber networks. Furthermore, mechanical properties of the braiding yarns are deteriorated by the cutting process. Therefore, the bending strength of the cut composites is considerably decreased. Distribution of the reduction units is the most important factor that causes property differences between the column yarn-reduction composites and the row unit yarn-reduction composites. When the reduced yarns are arranged in the same columns, free yarn ends and pores are close to each other, which are likely to become the weak zones and influence bending properties of the column yarn-reduction composites. On the contrary, distribution of the reduction units is uniform and dispersive in the row unit yarn-reduction composites; thus, concentrative structural defects are avoided and higher bending properties can be got.

SEM images of the fracture surfaces of the row unit yarn-reduction composites, column yarn-reduction composites and cut composites are shown to analyze their failure mechanisms. For the row unit yarn-reduction composites, tiny matrix crackings tend to initiate near the resin pocket regions and then propagate along the local yarn orientation angles in saw-tooth patterns. Carbon yarns do not experience obvious plastic deformation until final rupture and rough fracture surfaces can be seen (Figure 10). The column yarn-reduction composites have similar failure modes to the row unit yarn-reduction composites but the damage is more serious due to their lower bending properties. Debondings between yarns and matrix occur with the increase of the bending load and more yarns break ultimately (Figure 11). The integrate fiber networks of the cut composites are ruined by cutting. The matrix is more susceptible to be squeezed and deformed in the looser structures. The matrix on the surface of the cut composites is even broken into pieces and falls off (Figure 12). From the analysis above, the primary failure mechanism of the yarn-reduction composites is yarn breakage, whereas matrix cracking and interfacial debonding are the dominant failure mechanisms of the cut composites. Figure 10.
Failure mechanisms of the row unit yarn-reduction composites: (a) matrix crackings in saw-tooth patterns; (b) yarn breakage with a rough fracture surface. Figure 11.
Failure mechanisms of the column yarn-reduction composites: (a) interfacial debonding; (b) yarn breakage. Figure 12.
Failure mechanisms of the cut composites: (a) yarn continuity damage; (b) matrix cracking and falling off.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Tapered 3D braided composites can be net shape prepared by the yarn-reduction or yarn-addition techniques. The basic principle of these two techniques is that the braiding rules should not be disturbed after yarn reduction or yarn addition. A smoothly trapezoidal shape is formed near the yarn-reduction cross-section. Orientation degrees and lengths of some rearranged yarns are increased in the second step after yarn reduction, whereas the other rearranged yarns only reverse their orientation directions, then the yarn trajectories are the same as before yarn reduction in subsequent steps. The average bending strengths and bending moduli in the tapered regions of the row unit yarn-reduction composites and column yarn-reduction composites are significantly higher than those of the cut composites, while the row unit yarn-reduction composites have slightly better bending properties compared with the column yarn-reduction composites. Yarn breakage is the primary failure mechanism of the yarn-reduction composites, and matrix cracking and interfacial debonding are the dominant failure mechanisms of the cut composites.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant numbers 50809016 and 10872048); the Innovation Foundation for the Doctoral Thesis of Donghua University (grant number BC201015); and the Fund of National Engineering and Research Center for Commercial Aircraft Manufacturing (grant numbers SAMC11-JS-07-221, SAMC11-JS-07-219).
